entry.title: Niket and Rupal presented at SciTech 2025!

link.title: Niket and Rupal presented at SciTech 2025!

entry.content: Niket and Rupal presented two papers at the 2025 AIAA SciTech Forum. Niket presented a paper titled “Inefficiency of Self-Interested Behaviour in Markov Games: State-Dependent Price of Anarchy” which was a Finalist for the ISTC SciTech Student Paper competition. Rupal presented a paper titled “A Survey of Current Applications of Inverse Reinforcement Learning in Aviation and Future Outlooks.”

entry.summary: Niket and Rupal presented two papers at the 2025 AIAA SciTech Forum. Niket presented a paper titled “Inefficiency of Self-Interested Behaviour in Markov Games: State-Dependent Price of Anarchy” which was a Finalist for the ISTC SciTech Student Paper competition. Rupal presented a paper titled “A Survey of Current Applications of Inverse Reinforcement Learning in Aviation and Future Outlooks.”

entry.title: Our paper on explainable RL was accepted to L-CSS!

link.title: Our paper on explainable RL was accepted to L-CSS!

entry.content:
Our paper “On Generating Explanations for Reinforcement Learning Policies: An Empirical Study” was accepted to IEEE Control Systems Letters! We present a local-search method for explaining reinforcement learning policies using temporal logic. This work was led by Miki Yuasa.

Check out the paper!

entry.title: Jacob presented at the RLC 2024 CoCoMARL Workshop!

link.title: Jacob presented at the RLC 2024 CoCoMARL Workshop!

entry.content:
Jacob gave a poster presentation of our paper “Coordination Machines for Minimizing Communication in Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning” at the Coordination and Cooperation in Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (CoCoMARL) Workshop at the Reinforcement Learning Conference (RLC) 2024! We present a hierarchical method for minimizing communications subject to mission success requirements.

Check out the paper!

entry.summary: Jacob gave a poster presentation of our paper “Coordination Machines for Minimizing Communication in Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning” at the Coordination and Cooperation in Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (CoCoMARL) Workshop at the Reinforcement Learning Conference (RLC) 2024! We present a hierarchical method for minimizing communications subject to mission success requirements.

entry.title: We are awarded funding from the NASA TTT program!

link.title: We are awarded funding from the NASA TTT program!

entry.content:
Our project titled “Learning from Existing Systems for Emergent Coordination in Future Air Mobility” is selected for funding by NASA’s Transformational Tools and Technologies (TTT) program! Advanced Air Mobility (AAM) missions will require a wide range of use cases, such as urban air mobility (UAM) and firefighting, where vehicles, operators, and services coordinate with each other to satisfy mission objectives. Distributed autonomy, where autonomous vehicles rely on vehicle-to-vehicle communications to coordinate, is a key enabler for this vision, as the desired scale of operations will surpass capabilities of current operational architectures, which require centralized coordination and significant human oversight. This project aims to create methods for dynamic coordination of collective autonomous air mobility systems (CAMS), by drawing insights from existing systems in other domains involving mobility and human-autonomy interactions. Our key idea is to use a hybrid approach that leverages: (1) multi-agent inverse reinforcement learning (MA-IRL) to extract general mechanisms for emergent behavior from eCAS, and (2) multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) to incorporate those mechanisms into algorithms for dynamic coordination in CAMS.

This project is a collaboration with Dr. Max Li from the University of Michigan.

entry.summary: Our project titled “Learning from Existing Systems for Emergent Coordination in Future Air Mobility” is selected for funding by NASA’s Transformational Tools and Technologies (TTT) program! Advanced Air Mobility (AAM) missions will require a wide range of use cases, such as urban air mobility (UAM) and firefighting, where vehicles, operators, and services coordinate with each other to satisfy mission objectives. Distributed autonomy, where autonomous vehicles rely on vehicle-to-vehicle communications to coordinate, is a key enabler for this vision, as the desired scale of operations will surpass capabilities of current operational architectures, which require centralized coordination and significant human oversight. This project aims to create methods for dynamic coordination of collective autonomous air mobility systems (CAMS), by drawing insights from existing systems in other domains involving mobility and human-autonomy interactions. Our key idea is to use a hybrid approach that leverages: (1) multi-agent inverse reinforcement learning (MA-IRL) to extract general mechanisms for emergent behavior from eCAS, and (2) multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) to incorporate those mechanisms into algorithms for dynamic coordination in CAMS.

entry.title: Our work on ad hoc teaming was accepted to the IROS 2023 Multi-Agent Learning Workshop!

link.title: Our work on ad hoc teaming was accepted to the IROS 2023 Multi-Agent Learning Workshop!

entry.content: Our paper “Coordination in Ad Hoc Teams with Generalized Policy Improvement” was accepted for a 5 minute lightning talk at the IROS 2023 Multi-Agent Learning Workshop! We show that generalized policy improvement allows an agent to leverage prior training for fast adadptation to new teammates in cooperative tasks.

entry.title: Huy gave an invited workshop talk at RSS 2023!

link.title: Huy gave an invited workshop talk at RSS 2023!

entry.content: Huy gave an invited talk at the RSS 2023 Inference and Decision Making for Autonomous Vehicles Workshop. The talk was titled “Learning for Decision Making in Cooperative Multi-agent Systems.”

entry.title: Huy gave an invited workshop talk at IROS 2022!

link.title: Huy gave an invited workshop talk at IROS 2022!

entry.content: Huy gave an invited talk at the IROS 2022 Decision Making in Multi-agent Systems Workshop. The talk was titled “On Utilities for Cooperative Multi-agent RL.” A video link to the talk can be found here.

entry.title: Our work on robot navigation was accepted to RA-L!

link.title: Our work on robot navigation was accepted to RA-L!

entry.content: Our paper “WayFAST: Navigation with Predictive Traversability in the Field” was accepted for publication in IEEE RA-L! We present a new method for robot navigation in the field using traversability estimations.

entry.title: Our work on anomaly detection was accepted to IJCNN 2022!

link.title: Our work on anomaly detection was accepted to IJCNN 2022!

entry.content: Our paper “D-AnoGAN: Anomaly Detection in Disconnected Data Manifolds with Generative Adversarial Networks” was accepted for presentation at IJCNN 2022! We explore the problem of unsupervised anomaly detection in disconnected data manifolds. We show that a multi-generator network can be combined with a bandit to learn to cluster data into different manifolds, leading to improved performance on several datasets.

author.name: {"links"=>[{"label"=>"Urbana, IL", "icon"=>"fas fa-map-marker-alt", "url"=>"https://aerospace.illinois.edu/"}, {"label"=>"Email", "icon"=>"fas fa-fw fa-envelope-square", "url"=>"mailto:huytran1@illinois.edu"}, {"label"=>"Google Scholar", "icon"=>"fa fa-graduation-cap", "url"=>"https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=TgaPukcAAAAJ&hl=en"}, {"label"=>"GitHub", "icon"=>"fab fa-fw fa-github", "url"=>"https://github.com/tran-research-group"}]}

entry.summary: Our paper “D-AnoGAN: Anomaly Detection in Disconnected Data Manifolds with Generative Adversarial Networks” was accepted for presentation at IJCNN 2022! We explore the problem of unsupervised anomaly detection in disconnected data manifolds. We show that a multi-generator network can be combined with a bandit to learn to cluster data into different manifolds, leading to improved performance on several datasets.

entry.title: Our work on hierarchical RL was accepted to ALA Workshop 2022!

link.title: Our work on hierarchical RL was accepted to ALA Workshop 2022!

entry.content:
Our paper “Feature Specialization and Clustering Improves Hierarchical Subtask Learning” was accepted for presentation at the Adaptive Learning Agents (ALA) Workshop 2022 (AAMAS)! We show that feature specialization and clustering improve hierarchical reinforcement learning (RL) in various spatial planning tasks, through our Specialized Neurons and Clustering (SNAC) method.

Check out the talk and paper!
